requires.py.message: I'm not 100% happy with the lack of broken processing which requires a when_not joined handler - this seemed to break in my testing due to a lack of the object associated with the interface being passed to the handler.

After reviewing in more detail I think this is fine - update_flags will deal with clearing the connected flags once all units have disappeared so the rebase reliable reproduces what the original RelationBase class did behaviourally.

why are we iterating through all the relations instead of just going through the ones in `relation_info` as before ?

It seems as though this could be called multiple times - which is fine - except there doesn't appear to be any way to ensure that we aren't sending slightly different relation information.

This in effect reproduces what set_remote does in the old RelationBase class with Scope.GLOBAL - when data is set, it gets set across all instances of the relation associated with the endpoint.

relation_info is just the dict of keys that gets keyword expanded by **.

1. What happens if download fails at upload, i.e running "system application-upload -i <application>"?

2. Another that I see is that 'remove-failed' is a dead-end, meaning that one cannot change the state of an application if 'remove-failed' is reached. Should we provide the possibility to run "delete --forced" or "remove --forced" against a 'remove-failed' app?

1. state goes to 'upload-failed'. 'remove' operation won't do anything and returns message: "Application-remove rejected: operation is not allowed while the current status is upload-failed.". 'delete' operation deletes the app.

2. I am for this.

So does this mean that https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/855516 (force remove) is not really needed (i.e. this issue was the root case getting into the failed state). Or is it handling other failure scenarios?
This issue was the root cause for the specific case reported, but as Lucas pointed out we didn't have a way in the appfwk to fix a remove-failed state, the app would just get stuck.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> If the network does not external=True, it cannot be added to the router, how does the BGP speaker advertise dynamic routes? In addition, the BGP speaker is to advertise the tenant network, but the tenant network is bound to the BGP speaker as a gateway, Is this reasonable?

Advertisement of routes is completely independent of routing, the BGP speaker is in the control plane, not in the data path, in a usual deployment. The network can have external routers connected even if external=False.

I was going through change[1] and there we are removing this additional logic we added in this patch. Not sure what we're trying to achieve here.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/844962
The tests and code change are not related but we're removing a redundant decorator and improving testing so should be acceptable. LGTM.

As I've noted in the next patch, the pattern we've used here is weird and has led to a bug (which we're fixing here). I'd ultimately like to remove that pattern, however, it's a tricky areas so I've decided to fix it in two steps:

1. Fix the immediate mistake and add tests to prevent regressions (i.e. this patch). This is backportable.
2. Change the pattern to something easier to understand (i.e. the next patch). This isn't really backportable IMO.

I could have done everything in one patch but it would be larger and more difficult to understand. While the bugfix here is effectively useless once I migrate to the new pattern, the tests are not and the bugfix helps us understand how things are currently working before we change to a different pattern in the next file.

Hopefully this helps clarify things.
Thanks for the explanation, the code changes seems counterproductive but since we're addressing it in the end. it should be good.

> Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1
> * Either the run or failing playbook should start expanded.

This is fixed in PS5
 
> While this is less critical, this does appear to use a smaller font than everything else.  Can we keep it the same as the rest of the body text?

PS6 overrides the datalist to use --pf-global--FontSize--md which should make it consistent
 
> Also, since this can't be checked in a preview build -- would you please confirm that the deep link to a task still works?

Yes, when I am using localhost:3000, opening the permalink on the modal page does take you directly to the result

> * The magnifying glass was located next to the result as a secondary indication that the result is clickable.  They don't really need to be different columns.  Is it possible to approximate the old layout?  They both also used to have a tooltip.

In PS7 I have moved these into the same cell into a flexbox, and put tooltips on each
 
> * We don't really need the untrusted label.  It's sort of the "normal" case, so it's not adding anything (except visual noise).  The trusted label also used to have a tooltip.

This did have a popover, but I've converted it to a tooltip in PS7.  I've removed the untrusted label

> * The font on the nodeset is still small (but the rest look better).

In PS7 I have made this the md-size font.

> * There's a lot of extra vertical space between rows -- enough that it's actually a bit hard to scan (though the horizontal line counteracts that a bit) and users will need to scroll a lot more to find information now.  How does it look with less vertical padding (and possibly removing the horizontal line if that gets too crowded)?

patternfly really just has a "normal/compact" option for this, and we're already on compact.  There's quite a few padding variables going on in the various elements of the datalist that will need class overrides; simiarly pf doesn't have a single option to remove lines, but we can override classes.  

I'm hesitant to start fiddling at this level in this already large change.  My preference would be to start with the default PF compact layout, and we can follow-on by getting some wider feedback and come up with a more targeted change that only deals with this, where we can side-by-side compare options?

> Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> * The tasks have different indentations depending on whether they have carets or not.

Noted inline, this is a limitation of the DataList view unfortunately [1]; it seems the workaround with PS4 works with localhost:3000 but not on the preview site (I really have no idea why...).  PS6 has a different workaround using a minimum-width inline span which looks good to me on firefox and chrome at least (both on localhost and on the preview site)

[1] https://github.com/patternfly/patternfly/issues/5055

Thanks!  I understand the hesitancy to start changing the CSS -- though we do it in several other places.  This format has 70% of the information density of the old layout, and I don't think anyone ever said that was too dense, so I do think it's worthwhile to try to get back to that level.  I also agree that doing so in a separate change that can stand or fall on its own is a good idea.
https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/855297 is a separate change for fiddling css

In this try clause, only `sol_ex.SolException` can be raised in `raise_sol_exception` method referred by `do_request`. So it should be refactored as follows:

```
    except sol_ex.SolException:
```
I think this if clause should be placed outside of try-except clause, because the raise statement will be redundant since it will be trapped soon at except clause.

- Please use `raise...from` if you re-raise exceptions for the readable traceback.
- As I mentioned above, try clause should only contain L98. Therefore, exceptions that will be trapped at this except clause will be only `sol_ex.SolException`.

So I suggest the refactor of L97-L103 as follows:

```
try:
    resp, _ = client.do_request(url, "GET")
except sol_ex.SolException as e:
    raise sol_ex.TestNotificationFailed() from e
    
if resp.status_code != 204:
    raise sol_ex.TestNotificationFailed()
```

Here is going to be the testing workflow:
1. In content provider job
  - dlrn will build the depends-on patches and put it in gating repo
  - containers will get built with the gating repo and served on the content provider
2. In child job
  - child job will pull tripleo-ansible-ee container and consume it in the respective child job where tripleo-ansible-ee container will be used to run tripleo-ansible playbook.

https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:standalone-roles-testing contains the series of patchs to pull on the host under test. It is still in progress.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/+/854337/5/config/general_config/featureset053.yml#35 will pull the container on the child job.

I can comment out this line and rebuild this container on cs8 wallaby container line.

To be able for ansible to deal with the arbirtray uid's that Openshift is enforcing in its default scc, it would be necessary to add "RUN chmod g=u /etc/passwd /etc/group" to the tcib file so the subsequent image let the operator set temporary permissions on the openshift uid for ansible to work.

We are still lacking a ln -s /usr/share/ansible/roles /runner/roles, as most of the playbooks are referencing the roles they run as ../roles/<whatever>. If we invoke them from /runner/project and roles is not in /runner/roles, this will fail.

I would suggest to remove the cmd as due to openshift usage of arbitrary uids, nothing that is not executed via the entrypoint.sh script will work. Also, the "worker" command runs the ansible playbook on the background, which would cause the closing of the container without actually running the playbook. +1 please add more details - what would be new config options, what are proposed haproxy config changes, etc
So will metadata service stay vulnerable to "DDoS" from multiple sources?

I think so, at least in theory. In practice, if end-users cannot forge the source-IP of their instance in a way that the metadata can answer to, they'll need the assistance of the control plane to get more source IPs in order to effectively DDoS metadata.
From what we have seen, end-users are generally not trying to cause harm when they query metadata 10 times a second; they usually don't even realize they do it.

That said, the load caused by all the metadata queries over the whole region are also a concern to us, even after accounting for the rate-limiting we are discussing. It would be nice to discuss mitigation of issues like the thundering herd problem, but I feel this should be done through another RFE.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I agree that's worth considering.  I've marked this change WIP and moved it to the end of the stack until we decide on that.

I haven't been able to fully review this change yet, but this parenthetical concerns me. I think it is helpful that nodepool labels provide a consistent result (at least within a cloud provider). OpenDev for example has gone through a lot of effort to try and normalize this as much as possible and where not possible add new labels instead. The reason for this is that it is confusing to users when they ask for something and get what they perceive to be vastly different.

Would it be better to address this by specifying in the job itself that the job can be run on one of multiple labels? Then you can have different labels for the different valid types? This was it is more explicit to the user that they are accepting variance.

This sounds like a bug in the ovn-octavia-driver.

The third party drivers "own" the status fields and push that data up to Octavia via the driver-agent.
There is no reason a third party driver should need Octavia to provide them the status of their load balancer objects, the third party driver should know these statuses and be telling Octavia what they are so that Octavia can provide the user this information via the API (i.e. bulk status calls, etc.).

Drivers need to adhere to the interface specification published here: https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/contributor/guides/providers.html

Also, any change to the data model requires associated documentation changes.

tobiko/shell/ss.py.message:
Is it possible to add the output of the command for both tcp_listening and unix_listening?
In my case, that would help me to understand why the method extend_ports is needed
Thanks!

I didn't add support for collecting both types at the same time (or tcp or unix). The idea of the method is that the header has a single title for both 'address' and 'port'. In tcp/udp sockets addresses divided from ports using ':' so we can still split the line with just whitespace symbol. in unix sockets header remains the same but the data is the following "/file/name *" so we can't split the line the same way as the amount of elements in the list will not be equal to the number of elements in header

For better readability:

    command = """awk '
        BEGIN {f=""}                     # initialize f
        /fatal: \[/ {f=""}               # reset f on first match
        /fatal: \[/,/PLAY RECAP/ {       # capture text between two delimiters
            if ($0 ~ /PLAY RECAP/) next  # exclude last delimiter
            if ($0 == "") next           # exclude blank line
            f = f ? (f "\\n" $0) : $0    # assign or append to f
        }'
        END {print f}
        '""" + files_for_search

I understand that this is a fix that improves performance for CHECK_INTERVAL by starting "create_stack" after confirming DELETE_COMPLETE with "wait_stack_delete".
However, the maximum possible reduction with this fix is the 5 seconds set in CHECK_INTERVAL, which I think is insignificant.

So I thought this fix was unnecessary, what do you think?

specs/xena/update_original_volume_az.rst.message: please make clear that you mean user as operator here, not end user.
Ok, got it, thanks for review.

Would this command be allowed to update volumes that are in-use?  Should there be a check that all volumes are in "available"?

Similarly, we need to check for volumes that are in a consistency group -- other volumes in that group would need an update, as would the group itself.

specs/yoga/update_original_volume_az.rst.message:
A few questions:

1. Does the operator have to do anything before running the 'cinder-manage volume update_az' command (for example, make sure all the volumes that are affected are in 'available' status)?  Or is that not a concern (if not, please say why this isn't a problem for in-use volumes).

2. Similar question about backups, snapshots (if it's not relevant, say so).

3. Please say something about what the command will do ... I take it that it will look up the AZ of the specified backend, then find all volumes/backups/snapshots on that backend, and update them?

4. Is there a reason to split the commands like this?  What I mean is, is there a use case for an operator calling 'cinder-manage volume update_az' but not also calling 'cinder-manage backup update_az'?

5. What about generic groups and consistency groups?  Will the tool update these, or do they need to be done by hand (like volume-types?)?

It's possible for a volume-type to specify an availability zone.  You need to point out that this tool won't address that: any such volume types will have to be updated individually by the operator (as they do now).

I know this is following the existing pattern, but this would be better in a post-deploy role, rather than using a template in the common role.

I have a few issues with this.

1. Files in /etc/ owned by a non-root user is a bit odd.

2. This is a global location - at least ~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml would be better on a multi-user system.

3. Even ~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml isn't ideal if I'm managing multiple clouds (e.g. a staging and production system).

4. It will overwrite an existing non-kolla clouds.yaml file (which can be a bit fiddly to set up, perhaps including a few clouds).

Alternatively, we could write to e.g. {{ node_config }}/clouds.yaml. Let the user copy this into place, or set OS_CLIENT_CONFIG_FILE (poorly documented, but mentioned here: https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/guides/connect_from_config.html#user-defined-location)
I agree with Mark's comments to make it better / safer.

Handing further implementation to team in charge of build-tools. I'll abandon this change when needed.

Unfortunately the original code treats snapshots and published repos as one entity. Thus we get into this situation where creating a new snapshot tears the publication, then the snapshot before then attempting to create a new snapshut (reusing the original name). This should all take place at a higher level where better decision making can be programmed in, handling the error cases better.

Your change does revive the publication when the new snapshot fails creation. But since snapshots and publications are being treated as one entity you now have a new (old) snapshot name (backup-[name]) that is not named the same as the snapshot ([name]). This will have implications, such as does this snapshot ever get cleaned up?

I am not putting this on you, the original code should have not linked snapshots and publications in this way. To be safe I would suggest you restore the snapshot name, then just create the publication again. This will require moving the publication code out of the snapshot functions.

Basically there have been instances of DIB breakage by external dependencies (Rocky Linux container Dockerfile bugs or changes in qcow2 images done by e.g. CentOS) - that were fixed by DIB point releases - so if we limit them - we will need to bump them at some point in time.

DIB is basically branchless with tags, we'll have python3.9 and 3.10 in Zed, security support for 3.9 ends in Oct 2025 - so no risk we'll need to fix it before Zed EOL.
My five cents is that probably we'll benefit from not pinning, but I'm fine with pinning to latest tag as of Kayobe Zed release date.
From past experience, I think we are more likely to see breakage due to pinning (due to external resources such as rocky-container changing) than not pinning.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This isn't quite correct; the properties had been added, they just weren't being serialized properly.  I suggest something like:

Serialize message_* properties of RequestContext

Change Idc00b125b33b added the ability to store and retrieve user message data in the request context, but it neglected to add code to make sure they would persist across serialization and deserialization of the request context object, as happens in the create-backup workflow.  As a result, when a user message needed to be created to describe an error condition in the backup driver, instead we'd get an exception raised: "TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable".

This patch fixes the issue by making sure the message_* properties persist across serialization/deserialization of RequestContext objects.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Haven't reviewed the code yet, but wanted to respond to Rajat's microversion concern.  I think if we look at this from the end user point of view:

delete - no change, if I created a transfer and now want to cancel it, I simply delete it; I shouldn't have to specify mv 3.70  because nothing has changed for me

accept - no change; I simply accept the transfer or ignore it

create - this one is different; pre-3.70, if I tried to transfer an encrypted volume, the create would fail, and it's possible I've relied on that to prevent me from transferring an encrypted volume by mistake.  So to get the new functionality, I should ask for mv 3.70 or greater, and that makes sense.

So I think Alan's approach makes sense.
I'm good with the current approach. some of the comments left previously needs to be addressed.
The general idea looks good. I've few questions and suggestions inline.
Zuul has passed. My queries/comments have been addressed. So +1.

Yes, my cases have been more rare to think about in a kind-of upgrade scenario but the main reasoning was to only allow an operation, like to accept an encrypted volume, only when we've specified the microversion.
Thinking about it again, an accept of encrypted volumes won't occur if we aren't able to create a transfer with the required microversion and users running different API services with different microversion support in a deployment seems highly unlikely so I'm good with this approach.
If my other comments are addressed I'm good with it.
Code and tests look good and have helpful comments.  A few minor things noted inline, but nothing worth holding this up over.
Few comments which can be addressed in a followup but not critical. The general idea and code looks good to me.

cinder/api/v3/volume_transfer.py.message:
Since we don't have a spec, I'm not sure about the assumption we are making here but my question is, don't we require the same check for accept and delete transfer[1]?
Is a case possible when different c-vol services are running different openstack versions and the accept/delete request goes to a service which doesn't have support for 3.70 MV ?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/contrib/volume_transfer.py#L110-L145

Correct me if I'm wrong but since there are two users (in different projects) involved in the transfer, let's say user1 and user2.
If user1 has created a transfer (with the required MV) and user2 can't accept it (because of required MV) then user1 should be able to delete the transfer since they are on a version of cinder that supports required microversion for creating/accepting/deleting a transfer right?

Hmm, you raise an interesting point, but I'm not sure how to proceed. Yes, the current design does assume (perhaps falsely?) that if you can create the transfer, then your cloud is running a suitable version of cinder that can also accept or delete a transfer.

But if that's not the case, then where does that leave the user? I guess if the c-vol service cannot accept the transfer, then the only recourse is the delete it. But if we require a microversion check on the delete API, then where does that leave the user? We've stranded them halfway across the desert, and don't allow them either forward or back.

I'm happy to add mv checks on the accept and delete API, but it seems to hinge on whether the assumption I stated above is true or false.
Resolved in the new comment thread Brian initiated.

I think you mean user1 and user2 might have different versions of the cinderclient. I expect the version of cinder itself will be same for both, and consistent across the cinder services (namely c-api and c-vol).

This feature doesn't require anything special in the API beyond the mv that's currently necessary to create the transfer request. The mv is really there just to distinguish between the period when encrypted volumes couldn't be transferred and the mv that signals it's now possible. If cinder supports the transfer and user1 has a cinderclient that supports the mv, and knowing there's no other API change associated with the feature, I assumed it would be OK for user2 to accept the transfer regardless of their cinderclient and mv. Maybe that's the assumption under discussion.

As for deleting a transfer, if user1 has a client that supports the mv, then I don't see a value in rejecting a delete request unless they specify the mv again. I recognize that's another assumption on my part.

cinder/transfer/api.py.message:
Query: Would it be helpful if we mention here that ...
It is supported from mv 3.70 & later.

I don't think that's a good idea. I chose to keep the original text (including the awkward grammar) because it's the original response. I'm not aware of any precedence for modifying original responses so that they provide hints about new features.

Yes, we tend to be very conservative about this, though I could see how it could be helpful.  Problem is that if someone has a script that's parsing the returned string, we don't want to break them.  But it might be worth thinking about this (not just for this mv, there could be others), maybe at the PTG.
we are performing this after destroying the transfer record from DB, if this step fails, don't we want to preserve the DB record?
You're right, I think I need to move these two lines above L80.

I don't think we require a DB transfer record to do this.
I would suggest doing this before L#166 so we don't have to cleanup the transfer record in case of an exception.

My thinking was that it might be "dangerous" to transfer the key without a valid transfer record, but it's easy to delete the DB record if the transfer fails. If we swap the order by transferring the key first, then it will need to be swapped back if something happens when the DB record is created (L176). The exception handler starting at L177 will need to swap the key back, but what if that operation fails? It would leave the volume in an unusable state.
Ack, makes sense. We have to do work both ways and this is lesser so I'm OK with this.
Question: if this step errors out, do we need to revert the DB operations L#305-313 which performs accept transfer?

I believe that would leave the volume in an unusable state. My thinking here is the accept operation would fail, and there would be enough information left behind (in the DB record) to facilitate efforts to manually repair the problem.

Ack. While I feel the most likely place an exception might occur is the call at L305, which is before the key is transferred, your suggestion looks good (though I rearranged the code a little in my next patchset).

I agree that the DB operations required to put the transfer in original state seems non-trivial and moving this code before the DB call to transfer is doable but could open more possibilities for issues.

I'm good with this but just mentioning my approach if you would like to think about it,

move the key transfer code before the DB call for transfer accept
enclose the transfer_accept db call in try except
if the DB call fails, create a key transfer from current project to service project

this will move the key back to service project which was the original state

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> If we're going to rely on this, would we expect all prospective contributors to the repository to sign their commits, and not approve their changes until they got it figured out? While the additional traceability is nice,  it seems like it would raise the complexity of contributing even more than we already have.

No, I don't see us relying on this or requiring this -- certainly not the intent.

Just if people are choosing to sign their commits, we can keep a record of the key they are doing that with here.  I mean, it would be good to have everything signed *if* we ended up in a situation where we didn't trust what was on disk for some reason.  But even so, it seems that even having partially signed changes in that case at least reduces any potential audit footprint?

If it did become a required thing, I think it would have to be much more integrated into the workflow from gerrit, which it certainly isn't atm.

There is lots of algorithm duplication here and repeated walking of the process tree and repeated parsing of per pid data (even for the same pids), so that is inefficient but technically OK only if this algorithm is called infrequently.

I think the reason you had trouble using the existing above algorithm to process the memory is that you didn't have access to the pid's process name. So that you are getting from psutil, and alternatively could have used /proc/<pid>/comm .

Without a big refactor of this to parse the data only once (including my above algorithm, my your below groupings by hirunner process), recommend the following:

Create a dictionary to store what you want per pid. Populate this dictionary ONCE that doesn't require subsequent conversions.

e.g., Only do this once
mempid = {}
for process in psutil.process_iter():
    pid = int(process.pid)
    name = str(process.name()
    pct = round(process.memory_percent(), 4)
    rss = str(approximate_size(process.memory_info().rss)
    mempid[pid] = {
        'name': name,
        'pct': pct,
        'rss': rss,
    }

I didn't handle the 'try' exceptions...

// So even if you keep your existing path os.walk and children etc, then change the usage below to something more similar to this, YMWV:

for pid_ in platform_pids:
    pid = int(pid_)
    name = mempid[pid]['name']
    pct = mempid[pid]['pct']
    rss = mempid[pid]['rss']

And your algorithm mostly stays the same,
if pct > 0.0:
    memory[pc.GROUP_PROCESSES][pc.GROUP_PLATFORM][pid] = mempid[pid].copy()

Doing this will likely remove a level of try block within your algorithm since you did that first when you got the data the first time.
